stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a continuous intravenous infusion of heparin 25,000 units in 250 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride. The order is to administer heparin at 1200 units/hour. The IV pump is calibrated in mL/hour. At what rate in mL/hour should the nurse set the IV pump? (Record answer as a whole number. Do not include units.)

itemContext.sbar:
S: Jameson Tyrell is a 68-year-old male admitted for a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg. He is currently receiving a continuous heparin infusion. He denies any known drug allergies.

A: Mr. Tyrell has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, both managed with oral medications. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. He reports a pain level of 2 out of 10 in his left calf.

B: Mr. Tyrell was admitted yesterday at 18:00 with complaints of left leg pain and swelling. A lower extremity ultrasound confirmed the presence of a DVT. He was started on a heparin infusion per hospital protocol shortly after admission. He reports that the pain has decreased since starting the heparin.

R: Mr. Tyrell is receiving a continuous intravenous infusion of heparin 25,000 units in 250 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride. The current order is to administer heparin at a rate of 1200 units per hour. His vital signs are stable: blood pressure 140/88 mmHg, heart rate 82 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and SpO2 96% on room air. Recent laboratory results are available on the 'Labs' tab. The next heparin drip rate check is scheduled for 08:00. Please assess the IV site for patency and signs of infiltration. Monitor for any signs of bleeding, such as hematuria or melena, and report any concerns. Ensure PTT levels remain within the target therapeutic range of 60-80 seconds.

rationale.correct: 12. The calculation is as follows: (1200 units/hour) / (25,000 units/250 mL) = 12 mL/hour. Setting the IV pump to 12 mL/hour will deliver the ordered dose of heparin.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect calculations will result in either under- or over-dosing the patient with heparin, a high-alert medication. Heparin requires precise dosing to prevent complications such as bleeding or thromboembolic events. Always double-check calculations with another nurse, especially with high-alert medications.
clinicalPearls: Heparin is a high-alert medication requiring careful calculation and monitoring.
Always double-check medication calculations with another qualified nurse.
Monitor the patient's PTT to ensure therapeutic levels are maintained.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing units or performing the calculation in the wrong order can lead to a significant medication error. Some test-takers may incorrectly divide or multiply, resulting in an incorrect infusion rate. Others may forget to convert units correctly.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully review the problem, identify the desired unit (mL/hour), and set up the equation to ensure that unwanted units cancel out, leaving the desired unit. Double-check each step of the calculation.

mnemonic.title: Desired Over Have
mnemonic.expansion: D: Desired dose, O: Over, H: Have on hand = Amount to administer (D/H * Quantity)
